result.execSummary:
The defendant Dawn Marie Liegel was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • OWI (6th), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: In the Wisconsin State Prison System
Upon revocation, defendant is not eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program or the Wisconsin Substance Abuse Program.

miscConds.notes: AODA assessment and cooperate with any treatment. Maintain absolute sobriety with random urine screens.
No new law violations rising to the level of probable cause. Possess no prescription witout valid prescription. No driving without valid license.
Cooperate with the Department. Cooperate with any treatment deemed appropriate.
Seek and maintain full time employment.

Court ordered defendant pay a fine of $2,400.00 plus all applicable costs, fees and surcharges from bail on deposit with balance to be paid over probation; balance subject to civil judgment.  Upon revocation, to be paid through collection by the Department of Corrections from 25% of funds under Sec. 973.05(4)(b) and as a condition of extended supervision; any balance remaining unpaid at that time is to be converted to a civil judgment against the defendant.
Pursuant to Wisconsin Statutes section 973.176, the Court advised the defendant of the following restrictions:  Firearm possession; Voting.

Court ordered defendant provide DNA sample--pay surcharge over probation; balance subject to civil judgment.  Upon revocation, to be paid through collection by the Department of Corrections from 25% of funds under Sec. 973.05(4)(b) and as a condition of extended supervision; any balance remaining unpaid at that time is to be converted to a civil judgment against the defendant

timeConds.notes:
Good time with Huber for work and treatment and care for mother; conditional upon absolute sobriety. Defendant advised the court will not grant request to exceed maximum number of hours per day.

**03-26-15/ William S. Pocan**
The privileges previously granted are cancelled, and the defendant is sentenced to ordinary confinement for the balance of the term heretofore imposed.

Letter from defendant requesting clarification of fine owed and asking "time served credit" question.

Defendant Dawn Marie Liegel in court with attorney Allison Marie Ritter.  Sara Nicole Volden Schroeder appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant was advised of constitutional rights and maximum penalties, waived all rights, plead GUILTY and was examined as to the plea.  Plea Questionnaire/Waiver of Rights and Addendum received and filed.  Parties stipulate to the complaint as a factual basis for the plea.  Court found defendant guilty as charged in the Information and ordered entry of Judgment of Conviction.
**********
  Presentence report reviewed.  Statements made as to sentencing.
The Court sentenced the defendant to a MAXIMUM TERM OF IMPRISONMENT of 54 months, with credit for 3 days time served; the INITIAL TERM OF CONFINEMENT in the Wisconsin State Prison System is 30 months; the MAXIMUM TERM OF EXTENDED SUPERVISION is 24 months.  This sentence is stayed and defendant placed on PROBATION for a period of 3 years.  Upon revocation, the defendant is not eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program or the Wisconsin Substance Abuse Program.  
Terms of probation and extended supervision:
-Condition of probation:  12 months in the House of Correction-good time with Huber for work and treatment and care for mother; conditional upon absolute sobriety.  Defendant advised the court will not grant request to exceed maximum number of hours per day.  The court does not authorize electronic monitoring.
-No new law violations rising to the level of probable cause
-Cooperate with the Department
-AODA assessment and cooperate with any treatment
-Maintain absolute sobriety with random urine screens
-Cooperate with any treatment deemed appropriate.
-possess no prescription witout valid prescription
-No driving without valid license
-Seek and maintain full time employment

24 month driver license revocation
18 month ignigiton interlock
The court ordered defendant provide DNA sample--pay surcharge over probation; balance subject to civil judgment.  Upon revocation, to be paid through collection by the Department of Corrections from 25% of funds under Sec. 973.05(4)(b) and as a condition of extended supervision; any balance remaining unpaid at that time is to be converted to a civil judgment against the defendant    
The Court ordered defendant pay a fine of $2,400.00 plus all applicable costs, fees and surcharges from bail on deposit with balance to be paid over probation; balance subject to civil judgment.  Upon revocation, to be paid through collection by the Department of Corrections from 25% of funds under Sec. 973.05(4)(b) and as a condition of extended supervision; any balance remaining unpaid at that time is to be converted to a civil judgment against the defendant    

Pursuant to Wisconsin Statutes section 973.176, the Court advised the defendant of the following restrictions:  Firearm possession; Voting
